utterances: Unidentified Man #1: (Foreign language spoken)
Palestinians say they hope this is a step forward.
Mohammad Shardon's 30-year-old nephew Ismael(ph) was injured and spent a year in an Israeli jail during the first intifada or uprising in the early '90s.
A bullet fragment is lodged in his back near his spine he says and he's seeking medical treatment in Egypt he can't get in Gaza.
(Through Translator) We expect that this is the beginning for the way ahead.
We all looking forward to having the port open, the airport working and to have the road open from Gaza to the West Bank.
Under the agreement, bus travel between Gaza and the West Bank is scheduled to start in mid-December, the first regular transport between the areas in five years.
And Palestinians got the go-ahead to start building a new seaport.
In addition, cargo exports from Gaza's two main terminals, Karni and Kerem Shalom, are to increase next month.
Israel still controls the airspace and sea lanes around Gaza and there's no agreement in sight on reopening Gaza's airport, which was heavily damaged during the conflict.
But today, Ismael's 24-year-old wife, Halema Shardon(ph), isn't thinking about the politics of peace.
She says she's looking forward to getting away, to breathe.
(Through Translator) We really want to go and just enjoy ourselves and have some fun in Egypt.
We've been locked in here in Gaza for years doing ...(unintelligible).
Late in the afternoon, the Shardon family finally got through the crossing as the border was about to close.
Others weren't as lucky.
Unidentified Man #2: (Foreign language spoken)
Unidentified Man #3: (Foreign language spoken)
A despondent Maruf Abu Shar(ph), a wheelchair-bound stroke victim, sat in the blazing sun next to the main crossing gate.
He and his wife Esha(ph) were not among the some 1,500 people allowed to pass through today.
`They keep passing us from office to office,' she says, referring to the Palestinian police.
Her husband wept.
(Soundbite of crying)
(Foreign language spoken)
A chaotic and frustrating first day at the Rafah border crossing, but as one traveler said, `At least it's our chaos.'
Eric Westervelt, NPR News, at the Rafah border crossing, Gaza.
Poet Billy Collins wonders whether there's a surfeit of poetry in the world.
Yet verse begets verse in his new collection, ""The Trouble with Poetry: And Other Poems."" The former US poet laureate can go on at length about poetry's joys.
He says that adult readers are rediscovering their passion for the art and, in so doing, returning to their youth.
There are a greater percentage of people cohabitating today, than ever before.
This is the highest rate of cohabitation that we have seen, to date.
According to the latest results of a big government survey that's been tracking family dynamics for decades, almost half of those surveyed had lived with someone.
And that's a big jump from previous years.

As a matter of fact, I think a lot of polling shows that when you ask people afterwards - not only do they post-rationalize behavior, they sometimes convince themselves that they actually voted for the winner.
Post-talk, the polls show that the winner got a much higher percentage of votes than he ever or she ever really did.
Yes, definitely.
And so, what kinds of questions do you ask?
How do you figure out how people make up their minds there at your advertising agency?
Well, as brand experts, we believe it's imperative for leaders in the spotlight, and politicians especially, to manage their personal brand.
And to that end, we've been asking a number of questions to get at what people perceive are their assets and liabilities, what their associations are, both positive and negative.

In our most recent survey, we asked questions designed to determine the extent to which the candidates' families, their relationships with them and their religious affiliations affect voters' decisions.
So, who do you ask the questions to, a focus group of potential voters?
We have an online panel of 80,000-some people that we reach out to, 18 and older, and do this on a fairly regular basis.
And do you ask them about issues also?
We have not gone to the issue point yet because those issues aren't as clearly defined yet.
Oh, so you think that - is this what the campaigns are trying to do -define the people before they define the issues?
Well, I think they're trying to reach out to a number of people because there are still so many undecideds out there.
You see, in New Hampshire, Barack, McCain and Clinton trying to reach those independent voters in trying to get them to sway their way.
And you think that - but what you're saying is through all your research, people are responding to the emotional, the who the person is rather than what the person says?
Would your research be able to pick up if it were otherwise?
Later research will pick up on that.
But let's face it, the Democrats tend to stand for some of the same issues, that being universal health care, a withdrawal from the war on Iraq.
The Republicans also stand for some of the same issues.
But the difference is their - in their approaches, a lot of people would be hard-pressed to tell you what their approaches are just yet.
Mm.
Megan(ph) from Syracuse, New York.
Hi, Megan.
Hello.
How are you?
How do you decide about who you're going to vote for?
I know this may seem a little boring but I decide based on the issues.

I decide what's the biggest, most important issues for me, and that's got the most weight, and then I go on down the line and kind of decide who matches my viewpoints the best, and I vote for that person, and…
What is the biggest…
I must…
What is the biggest issue for you this election?
I'd have to say health care.
And I'd have to disagree with your guest in that I don't think, as a Democrat, that all Democratic candidates are the same as in - for universal health care.
Not all the plans proposed are universal.
I'm personally going to vote for Hillary Clinton.
Her plan is universal and has some good features to prevent the costs of the insurance from exceeding a certain percentage of anyone's income.
Issue-wise…
Barack Obama doesn't have a universal plan.
That's Barack Obama.
Issue-wise, what's the difference between Hillary Clinton and John Edwards?
Well, John Edwards on the health care issue and Hillary Clinton are very similar.
They have different perspectives on other issues.
I happen to think that Hillary Clinton is more focused on women and children and family issues than John Edwards is.
And that John Edwards is a little more focused on maybe fighting corporate America or the battle for its little guy, the common worker.
(unintelligible)…
But still, issues when deciding that…
…identify a little bit more with the former, I'm leaning that way.
So even when deciding between Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Edwards, it's still issues, issues, issues for you.
It's still issues.
All right.
Well, thanks very much for the call, Megan.
And so, Ann, is Megan unusual?
Well, again, I think that a lot of people would be hard-pressed to define the issues in the way that Megan just laid them out.
And whenever I make blanket statements like the Democrats stand for the same things, it's - you're always going to caveat it with one or two people who slightly differ.
But, you know, I think people are still trying to determine who stands for what and go deeper into how they stand on the issues.
And again, it's the - all in the approach and how they differ from one candidate to the other.
On the line with us is Ron Elving, NPR senior Washington editor.
Hey, Ron.
How are you?
